append: There was nothing so _very_ remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so _very_ much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself,  /newquote  (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually _took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket_, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.
dialogue: Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: thought Alice to herself,  /newquote  (Which was very likely true.)
dialogue: Well! /newquote after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they'll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn't say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Down, down, down. There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking again.  /newquote  (Dinah was the cat.)  /newquote  And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way,  /newquote  and sometimes,  /newquote  for, you see, as she couldn't answer either question, it didn't much matter which way she put it. She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly,  /newquote  when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.
dialogue: Dinah'll miss me very much to-night, I should think! /newquote I hope they'll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time. Dinah my dear! I wish you were down here with me! There are no mice in the air, I'm afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that's very like a mouse, you know. But do cats eat bats, I wonder? /newquote Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats? /newquote Do bats eat cats? /newquote Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: Alice began to get rather sleepy and went on saying to herself

append: And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this;  /newquote  said Alice to herself,  /newquote  And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.
dialogue: for it might end, you know, /newquote in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself,  /newquote , holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.
dialogue: Which way? Which way?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: She ate a little bit and said anxiously to herself

append: After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he came,  /newquote  Alice felt so desperate that she was ready to ask help of any one; so, when the Rabbit came near her, she began, in a low, timid voice,  /newquote  The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.
dialogue: Oh! the Duchess, the Duchess! Oh! won't she be savage if I've kept her waiting! /newquote If you please, sir--
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: he came trotting along in a great hurry muttering to himself

append: As she said these words her foot slipped, and in another moment, splash! she was up to her chin in salt water. Her first idea was that she had somehow fallen into the sea,  /newquote  she said to herself. (Alice had been to the seaside once in her life, and had come to the general conclusion, that wherever you go to on the English coast you find a number of bathing machines in the sea, some children digging in the sand with wooden spades, then a row of lodging houses, and behind them a railway station.) However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.
dialogue: and in that case I can go back by railway,
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice.
dialogue: Not like cats! /newquote Would _you_ like cats if you were me?
speaker: The Mouse
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice in a soothing tone:  /newquote  Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the pool,  /newquote  cried Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she felt certain it must be really offended.
dialogue: Well, perhaps not, /newquote don't be angry about it. And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah: I think you'd take a fancy to cats if you could only see her. She is such a dear quiet thing, /newquote and she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and washing her face--and she is such a nice soft thing to nurse--and she's such a capital one for catching mice--oh, I beg your pardon! /newquote We won't talk about her any more if you'd rather not.
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail.
dialogue: We indeed! /newquote As if _I_ would talk on such a subject! Our family always _hated_ cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don't let me hear the name again!
speaker: The Mouse
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation.  /newquote  The Mouse did not answer, so Alice went on eagerly:  /newquote  cried Alice in a sorrowful tone,  /newquote  For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.
dialogue: I won't indeed! /newquote Are you--are you fond--of--of dogs? /newquote There is such a nice little dog near our house I should like to show you! A little bright-eyed terrier, you know, with oh, such long curly brown hair! And it'll fetch things when you throw them, and it'll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts of things--I can't remember half of them--and it belongs to a farmer, you know, and he says it's so useful, it's worth a hundred pounds! He says it kills all the rats and--oh dear! /newquote I'm afraid I've offended it again!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: So she called softly after it,  /newquote  When the Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low trembling voice,
dialogue: Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won't talk about cats or dogs either, if you don't like them! /newquote Let us get to the shore, and then I'll tell you my history, and you'll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.
speaker: The Mouse
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she said to herself in a melancholy tone.  /newquote  And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited. In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.
dialogue: I wish I hadn't mentioned Dinah! /newquote Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I'm sure she's the best cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah! I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself  /newquote  Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen--everything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
dialogue: The Duchess! The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh my fur and whiskers! She'll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets! Where _can_ I have dropped them, I wonder?
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone,  /newquote  And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
dialogue: He took me for his housemaid, /newquote How surprised he'll be when he finds out who I am! But I'd better take him his fan and gloves--that is, if I can find them. /newquote W. RABBIT,
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

'Coming in a minute, nurse! But I've got to see that the mouse doesn't get out.' Only I don't think, /newquote that they'd let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time with the words  /newquote  but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips.  /newquote  she said to herself,
dialogue: DRINK ME, /newquote I know _something_ interesting is sure to happen, /newquote whenever I eat or drink anything; so I'll just see what this bottle does. I do hope it'll make me grow large again, for really I'm quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself
dialogue: That's quite enough--I hope I shan't grow any more--As it is, I can't get out at the door--I do wish I hadn't drunk quite so much!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: She hastily put down the bottle saying to herself

append: Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head. Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself
dialogue: Now I can do no more, whatever happens. What _will_ become of me?
speaker: The White Rabbit
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

Alice crouched down among the trees as well as she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.

append: It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes, and began talking to herself, as usual.  /newquote  As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open place, with a little house in it about four feet high.  /newquote  thought Alice,  /newquote  So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she had brought herself down to nine inches high.
dialogue: Come, there's half my plan done now! How puzzling all these changes are! I'm never sure what I'm going to be, from one minute to another! However, I've got back to my right size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden--how _is_ that to be done, I wonder? /newquote Whoever lives there, /newquote it'll never do to come upon them _this_ size: why, I should frighten them out of their wits!

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter, nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other, saying, in a solemn tone,  /newquote  The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone, only changing the order of the words a little,
dialogue: For the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen to play croquet. /newquote From the Queen. An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.
speaker: The Fish-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: he handed over to the other saying

append: said the Footman,  /newquote  And certainly there _was_ a most extraordinary noise going on within--a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.
dialogue: There's no sort of use in knocking, /newquote and that for two reasons. First, because I'm on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they're making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you.
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice,
dialogue: Please, then, /newquote how am I to get in?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: the Footman went on without attending to her,  /newquote  He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this Alice thought decidedly uncivil.  /newquote  she said to herself;  /newquote  she repeated, aloud.
dialogue: There might be some sense in your knocking, /newquote if we had the door between us. For instance, if you were _inside_, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know. /newquote But perhaps he can't help it, /newquote his eyes are so _very_ nearly at the top of his head. But at any rate he might answer questions.--How am I to get in?
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: the Footman remarked,
dialogue: I shall sit here, /newquote till tomorrow--
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly as if nothing had happened.
dialogue: --or next day, maybe,
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: asked Alice again, in a louder tone.
dialogue: How am I to get in?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Footman.
dialogue: _Are_ you to get in at all? /newquote That's the first question, you know.
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so.  /newquote  she muttered to herself,
dialogue: It's really dreadful, /newquote the way all the creatures argue. It's enough to drive one crazy!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his remark, with variations.  /newquote  he said,
dialogue: I shall sit here, /newquote on and off, for days and days.
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice.
dialogue: But what am _I_ to do?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Footman, and began whistling.
dialogue: Anything you like,
speaker: The Frog-Footman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice desperately:  /newquote  And she opened the door and went in.
dialogue: Oh, there's no use in talking to him, /newquote he's perfectly idiotic!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice said to herself, as well as she could for sneezing.
dialogue: There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried it out into the open air.  /newquote  thought Alice,  /newquote  She said the last words out loud, and the little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).  /newquote  said Alice;
dialogue: If I don't take this child away with me, /newquote they're sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn't it be murder to leave it behind? /newquote Don't grunt, /newquote that's not at all a proper way of expressing yourself.
speaker: The Duchess
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: No, there were no tears.  /newquote  said Alice, seriously,  /newquote  The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.
dialogue: If you're going to turn into a pig, my dear, /newquote I'll have nothing more to do with you. Mind now!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice was just beginning to think to herself,  /newquote  when it grunted again, so violently, that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time there could be _no_ mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.
dialogue: Now, what am I to do with this creature when I get it home?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: Alice was just beginning to think to herself

append: So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see it trot away quietly into the wood.  /newquote  she said to herself,  /newquote  And she began thinking over other children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying to herself,  /newquote  when she was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a tree a few yards off.
dialogue: If it had grown up, /newquote it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think. /newquote if one only knew the right way to change them--
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.  /newquote  thought Alice, and she went on.
dialogue: Cheshire Puss, /newquote Come, it's pleased so far, /newquote Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
dialogue: What sort of people live about here?
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: the Cat said, waving its right paw round,  /newquote  waving the other paw,

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice remarked.

append: Alice didn't think that proved it at all; however, she went on

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Cat,

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: the Cat went on,
dialogue: Well, then, /newquote you see, a dog growls when it's angry, and wags its tail when it's pleased. Now _I_ growl when I'm pleased, and wag my tail when I'm angry. Therefore I'm mad.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Alice.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in which the March Hare was said to live.  /newquote  she said to herself;  /newquote  As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
dialogue: I've seen hatters before, /newquote the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and perhaps as this is May it won't be raving mad--at least not so mad as it was in March.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Did you say pig, or fig?

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself
dialogue: Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost wish I'd gone to see the Hatter instead!
speaker: The Cat
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE
referringExpression: the March Hare said to itself

append: Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table.  /newquote  she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that led into the garden. Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and _then_--she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.
dialogue: Now, I'll manage better this time,
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself
dialogue: It's the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.
speaker: The Queen
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
dialogue: How are you getting on?
speaker: The Cat
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice began, in rather a complaining tone,
dialogue: I don't think they play at all fairly, /newquote and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can't hear oneself speak--and they don't seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them--and you've no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there's the arch I've got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground--and I should have croqueted the Queen's hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Cat in a low voice.
dialogue: How do you like the Queen?
speaker: The Cat
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and they walked off together.
dialogue: You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though),  /newquote  she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule,
dialogue: When _I'm_ a Duchess, /newquote I won't have any pepper in my kitchen _at all_. Soup does very well without--Maybe it's always pepper that makes people hot-tempered, /newquote and vinegar that makes them sour--and camomile that makes them bitter--and--and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew _that_: then they wouldn't be so stingy about it, you know--
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear.
dialogue: You're thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can't tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice ventured to remark.
dialogue: Perhaps it hasn't one,
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Duchess.  /newquote  And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice's side as she spoke.
dialogue: Tut, tut, child! /newquote Everything's got a moral, if only you can find it.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
dialogue: The game's going on rather better now,
speaker: Alice
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice whispered,

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice's shoulder as she added,

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Alice thought to herself.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

subject: NO MONOLOGUE
